✅So I'm visiting 9 farms tomorrow to talk about how #ClimateChange is impacting agriculture across #Massachusetts.

I'll use what I learn to keep fighting for a #GreenNewDeal so that future generations of farmers can continue to nourish our country and protect our land.

⌛️This isn't some far-off threat. 

Family farms are already losing money and producing less because of climate change. Yet in the halls of Congress, there's not nearly enough people listening to the farmers that are bearing the brunt of this crisis. https://www.masslive.com/opinion/2018/12/climate-change-and-farming-in-massachusetts-guest-viewpoint.html …

🌡️Raising temperatures. 
🦗Invasive species. 
🌪️Drought and unstable weather. 

Small family farms in Massachusetts are on the front lines of #ClimateChange. We need policies that help — yet too often, the rich and powerful write laws that favor big corporate farms instead.

🚜TOMORROW: I'm kicking off a two-day, district-wide farm tour to hear directly from farmers in central and western Massachusetts.

Thank you @Engage_Cuba for your important advocacy and leadership on this issue. It is beyond time for us to let the American people serve as ambassadors for our democratic values and let them travel freely to Cuba. https://twitter.com/Engage_Cuba/status/1154475090672623616 …

I believe that the American people are our very best ambassadors — that they reflect the democratic values, curiosity, and innovation that make our country so great. We ought to let them travel to #Cuba instead of doubling down on the failed policies of the past! https://twitter.com/nytopinion/status/1154409747996708866 …

This is an anachronistic policy, left over from the Cold War & proven to be ineffective at leveraging change by the Cuban government. The only people it harms are American citizens & those in Cuba striving to create economic alternatives to state-controlled enterprises.

Foreign governments might choose to deny our citizens a visa. They might restrict where Americans can go when they arrive inside a foreign country.  But the U.S. government and the U.S. Congress should not be in the business of imposing restrictions on our own citizens.

Cuba is the only country for which the U.S. maintains a travel ban. Americans can travel to China, Saudi Arabia, Vietnam, Russia, Iran & Syria – each with human rights records arguably as bad or worse than Cuba’s. Until  recently, Americans could even travel to North Korea.

The cruelty we are witnessing today is not an unintended consequence or side effect.

It is the goal.

If Trump wanted a solution, he would improve & expand case management programs instead of defunding them, & increase the number of specialized personnel to interview asylum seekers, especially families and children, so they may be processed quickly, professionally & humanely.

Then, in 2016, Trump terminated the “Family Case Management” program that even @ICEgov admits was 99% effective in having these families appear before a court. The program cost taxpayers about $38/day per family. In comparison, detaining families costs hundreds per day.
This framework has been upheld by past Republican & Democratic administrations, including during periods when the number of migrants coming to our southern border was 2 or 3x greater than it is now.

Let’s be clear: decades of U.S. asylum & immigration law (upheld time and again by U.S. courts) protects children & families seeking safe haven in the United States. These laws comply with international law, treaties and agreements the U.S. has signed.

We have been able to confirm what other Members of Congress have heard & seen:

-no showers for over 40 days.
-lights are kept on all night & people are sleeping on concrete floors.
-some are complaining they have gone hungry. pic.twitter.com/ob6kiwrCoQ
